title: Map Shows Poison Hanging In The Air Even Two Days After Diwali In India

Map Shows Poison Hanging In The Air Even Two Days After Diwali In India

Map Shows Poison Hanging In The Air Even Two Days After Diwali In India

Just when we thought this year the post-Diwali pollution would be different, the AQI in the national capital has spiked to as high as 999.

Earth Null School, which gives a visualization of global weather conditions, shows how bad the air is above the whole of North India, post Diwali.

The map allows you to alter dates just to see what it looked like a few months or weeks ago and we compared the representation from Oct 1 to Oct 29th - the results were jaw-dropping.

Take a look below:

Earth Null School

The Ministry of Earth Sciences' air quality monitor, SAFAR, on Monday, predicted that the share of smoke from stubble burning in Delhi's PM 2.5 concentration is likely to jump to 25 percent on Tuesday. It was 15 percent on Monday.

The period between October 15 and November 15 is considered critical as maximum number of stubble burning incidents takes place in this span, in Punjab and adjoining states. It is one of the main reasons for the alarming spike in pollution in Delhi-NCR.

But as the skies lit up with fireworks and the streets with crackers on Diwali, pollution levels peaked across north India.

With Delhi's air quality plummeting to dangerous levels around Diwali every year, the Supreme Court had in 2018 banned polluting firecrackers and ordered that only green firecrackers -which are said to cause 30 per cent less pollution - can be manufactured and sold. It also enforced a two-hour limit for setting them off.

The Arvind Kejriwal government also organised a mega laser show in an effort to dissuade people from bursting crackers.

However, a large number of revellers brazenly flouted the Supreme Court-enforced two-hour limit for bursting crackers this year too.

The AQI is expected to enter the 'severe' category in the upcoming days due to firecrackers, unfavorable weather, and significant stubble burning.

An AQI between 0-50 is considered 'good', 51-100 'satisfactory', 101-200 'moderate', 201-300 'poor', 301-400 'very poor', and 401-500 'severe'. Above 500 is 'severe-plus emergency' category.
